Posts.Content: cindy2 wrote: I am having a mastectomy on my non-cancer side in a few weeks.  Doing this for a number of reasons including cosmetics, need to have biopsies on the non-cancer side, and the fact that the uniboober look is doing nothing for me  The question is, do they do a sentinal node biopsy on the contralateral side during the mastectomy??  There seems to be some controversy and I would appreciate your experiences.  It seems that if they do not do the SNB and they find something in the breast, you have to have an axillary dissection because they can no longer find the sentinal nodes.  But if you do have the SNB and the breast is clear, you are exposed to the risks of SNB (lymphedema) without any benefit.  Any thoughts?  Experiences? Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2012 02:57PM cindy2 wrote: The mitotic index is a relative score of how many cancer cells are in the process of cell division at the time the biopsy was taken.  If many cells are dividing (a mitotic index of 3) the implication is that the tumor is fast growing.  Conversely, a low mitotic index (such as 1) indicates that the tumor is likely to grow slower.
